conclusion: Three states (A, B, and C) are visible on a V-T diagram for an ideal gas.
The goal is to solve for the pressure at state B using the ideal gas law and the given information.
State A has pressure pâ‚ = pâ‚€, temperature Tâ‚ = Tâ‚€, and volume Vâ‚ = Vâ‚€.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, indicating constant temperature.
Extension of line BC passes through the origin O.
Volume at state B is Vğµ = 2Vâ‚€.
The ideal gas law states that pV = nRT.
For a fixed mass of gas (constant n), pV/T = nR = constant.
At state A, pâ‚ = pâ‚€, Vâ‚ = Vâ‚€, Tâ‚ = Tâ‚€, therefore pâ‚€Vâ‚€/Tâ‚€ = nR.
Since AB is parallel to the V-axis, temperature is constant (Tğµ = Tâ‚ = Tâ‚€).
The volume changes from Vâ‚€ to 2Vâ‚€ during the transition from A to B.
For state B, Vğµ = 2Vâ‚€ and Tğµ = Tâ‚€, therefore pğµVğµ/Tğµ = pâ‚Vâ‚/Tâ‚ = nR.
Substituting the known values gives pğµ(2Vâ‚€)/Tâ‚€ = pâ‚€Vâ‚€/Tâ‚€.
Solving for pğµ results in pğµ = pâ‚€Vâ‚€/(2Vâ‚€) = pâ‚€/2.
The pressure of the gas in state B is pğµ = pâ‚€/2, which is half the pressure at state A.
